summary: A boy (Julian Dennison) and his foster father (Sam Neill) become the subjects of a manhunt after they get stranded in the New Zealand wilderness.

reviews.content:
If you are a fan of Taika Waititi then you will definitely love Hunt for the WilderPeople.

Taika Waititi can never do wrong. Everything he writes/directs never disappoints. Taika Waititi is brilliant! I'm pretty sure I've watched everything that has been released in North America. I can't wait until his next release 😄

There's some tense scenes and a lot of giggling scenes where I was giggling LOL it's just so good from start to finish.

I highly recommend it if you haven't seen it yet.

If you loved it before, watch it again and again 😉 I watch it about once a year 😄

This has Tika written all over it, his best work by far. It's fun, wholesome, and very well put together. Also I was supprised how beautiful some of the cinematography was. Great movie for the whole family. 97/100
Funny, wise and moving, Hunt for the Wilderpeople brings together an outstanding director and a solid cast to tell a well-grounded story that carries a noteworthy, yet powerful message.
Adorable and hilariously charming
Excellent film 🎥  Try to watch it every year

Julian Dennison and Sam Neill do the story proud in equal parts. Bella Faulkner is a standout in her part. It's an extraordinary story told well, and under the direction of Taika Waititi, it is absolutely excellent, and a movie that is easy and wonderful to watch over and over.
Hilarious and moving, Wilderpeople solidifies Taika Waititi as a genius director/writer with a gift for working with child actors.

Ricky (Julian Dennison), a young haiku-spouting want-to-be gangster, and his loving but gruff foster father (Sam Neill) are on the run from the authorities when they are advised that child services will be removing Ricky from the household.  Taika Waititi's Hunt for the Wilderpeople is, like all of Waititi's films, chock-full of quirkiness.  The characters are unique, the dialogue is fresh and funny, the soundtrack is always surprising, and the story is original.  The only potential problem with the movie is the Thelma and Louise-like climax, which feels wildly inconsistent with the tone of the rest of the film.  And always remember, you don't choose the skux life; the skux life chooses you.
Ohh geeeez, this one's cray cray. It hits ya right in the feels - but it's also very funny.
This is an entertaining, feel good, funny movie that you can watch with your family.  It's hard to come across gems like this movie these days.

The rebellious child arrives at foster parents, the lady loves him, the guy despises him, the woman dies, and then the man and the child set off on an adventure. It's entertaining to watch because of the general Disney vibe. Animal abuse is the kind that people are referring to. They are brutally murdered. Since everything turns out okay in the end, I suppose that kid could even watch this. Sometimes having the army involved goes a little too far. There are also some lovely images of the New Zealand wilderness.
Will be a kiwi classic forever. Box office: 23.2 million USD? Deserved 232 million USD box office
Made me laugh. Loved it.

Authentic and heartwarming, Hunt for the Wilderpeople relies on its endearing characters and great plot rather than its cast. Plus, it succeeds to deliver many well-placed laughters here and there as well as realistic action scenes, without going too far. A must-see for those who don't like busy, overfilled movies.
Top 3 favorite movies. Very good setting and characters, it feels long in a good way like an adventure but it doesn't get boring, the character growth is amazing. 10/10
Fabulous heart warming film which my tween son also loved.
Hilarious and heartwarming
Loved it, great scenery and acting. Funny and touching. Maybe easy to see where the plot was going, but that didn't matter at all.
Mother figure dies off early. Then it's a father figure-son in the woods with guns film. Snore. Enough of these already. Blah blah blah.

"| Ratings Categories |
{Characters (9.5/10) ; Cinematography (8.5/10) ; Plot (8.5/10) ; Acting (9.5/10) ; Pacing (8/10) = 88%}"

Funny offbeat humour throughout and a basic but sweet tale. Feels a bit Wes Anderson but simple impossible to hate and achieves the holy grail of remaining good natured and funny through the whole runtime. It's a fantastic low budget film. This is how it's done.
My favourite Taika Waititi film. Sooo cute.
Excellent. Funny and full of heart. Stick to this kind of stuff Taika.
Powerful message. Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a beautifully made New Zealand film perfectly written and balanced by a funny director and solid chemistry between the main characters.
Touching, funny, great acting, all ages.
Fun movie with great performances by Julian (the kid) and Sam Neill. A little kooky and very touching.

1ya- A sweetly written film set in a stunning, beautiful landscape manages to be elevated to an entirely different level due to the unbridled chemistry between a veteran of acting and a child actor and an offbeat sense of humor that could only come from Taika Waititi.

Some beautiful moments between characters. Excellent drama with much-needed humor throughout. Could be a bit slow-paced for average moviegoers but it's definitely a good story performed by brilliant actors.

A well-handled heartwarming and funny story. The two leads have a great comedic dynamic and they make some very compelling outcasts. I think the concept is quite creative and it's nice to see so much beautiful nature. The New Zealand setting adds a lot to the movies unique charm. A movie anyone can enjoy.

This movie is amazing.  The acting is stellar, and the writing and pacing are great.  The movie is a really sweet and funny tale that keeps you interested from the very beginning.  It was very enjoyable, funny and truly a joy to watch

I'm so happy that I was able to experienced this.

It's different, paced in a weird way, but ah so entertaining and funny and good.

Anything that Taika Waititi directs already starts off with 4 stars. He's just that good. This movie was pretty good, but there was something lacking for me with it. There was definitely some of those very clever moments that Taika is so good at, but maybe there just wasn't enough for me to keep the rating at 4 stars. Still a pretty good movie.
Good jokes, and a solid story.
Yeah, this is better than CATS.
Enjoyed this quite a bit, Taika still has no misses.
Another good movie as expected from Taika Waititi, and this one is another heartfelt, simple film based on a well written script and performed well by its actors.

"Majestical!"

Taika Waititi somehow manages to tread the line adeptly between tradegy and comedy to deliver a heart warming tale dealing with loss and isolation.

Funny, sad and proof that anything Taika touches turns to magic.

Julian Dennison as the hero Ricky should also be commended as his performance alongside a grizzled Sam Neil is what really grounds this film and got me compeltely invested.

Please watch. You will love it.

This is what a cinema experience should be. This film is a rollercoaster of emotions that span from laugh out loud humor to tear-jerking tragedy. Waititi is brilliant as always in his native realm of New Zealand cinema where comedy and tragedy and carefully measured to provide an accessible but emotional experience that goes far beyond the western "feel good" formula and reminds the viewer of the importance of pain as a contrast to joy.
Perfection. Taika Waititi is probably the best of his generation of filmmakers.

Wow! "The Hunt for the Wilderpeople" is wonderful. It's hilarious, wholesome, and adventurous. This is Taika Waititi at his finest. I honestly don't think anybody else could've done the source material justice. This is 100% Waititi. The dynamic between Hec and Ricky is great, and I think Sam has ever had a better performance. Oh, and Julian Dennison is remarkable. Such a great performance. All in all, this was an awesome movie, and I highly recommend it!
Really really funny, and endearing, and another testament to the NZ landscape! Great film.

Funny, exciting and emotionally compelling.
I'd recommend this movie to anyone.
brilliant, except for a decision one of the characters makes near the end of the film that is completely out of character

What I like about this movie the most is that it wears its influences on its sleeve. It's obvious that Waititi wrote this thing while watching Pixar's Up. From some of the dialogue in this movie, I was able to glean that after watching up he watched Terminator 2. Both of these movies are staples in my film collection as well. Yet when a subtext about 'No child left behind' is created, what ends up happening is lots of chuckling.  I wouldn't say this movie is the wild ride it aims to be, but nevertheless it is fun and at times funny and the writer/director is talented and has put out several successful films since this one; all these things considered I would recommend this one.
This is a trip filled by script and originality, though its cast helps a lot. 6/10

Though it had some awkward, somewhat rough moments technically, it was exceptionally sensitively written, well directed, cast and acted. Overall, it deserves all the stars. Yay for films that cherish humor and the best of humanity. Thank goodness for gems like this!!
Fun, emotional and action-packed movie. Brilliantly directed and brilliantly cast.
Amazing acting and story! Original funny but real! San Niel is awesome.
A good lighthearted movie. I missed some of the humor because the fast talking actors had Australian  accents.
quirky, funny, profound, silly, original

A truly majestical film.
I wish I could see it for the first time again.
Great movie with lots of heart.
Charming without being 'twee', this is the definition of a feel-good movie. With a deft and gentle touch, we're given an enjoyable exploration of what it is to find the people who understand you.
What a great movie funny, sad, happy and mad you will experience them all. Watch it you won't be disappointed. Awesome must see!
Taika Waititi proves his worth as a filmmaker with this hilarious, charming, off-beat comedy that warms my heart when I watch it. 9/10
Wonderful movie. Funny and good narration.

It's an old concept; A moody old man who wants nothing to do with an off-beat child, slowly comes around after they're forced together by circumstances. But this version of that story is fun. It has a lot of funny, lighthearted moments and director Taika Waititi's original kind of understated humor. - The movie starts to get away from itself in the second half of the movie, (a severely over-the-top child services officer, swat teams and car chases) but it comes around in the end. It's a nice, lighthearted movie.

Little late on this one, but it's really good. I believe Taika made this right before Thor Ragnarok and I saw how the score was similar to that blockbuster. This movie was quietly excellent. Taika has a great way of hitting you hard and soft with death, and isn't that just the way it happens in life sometimes too? This movie weaved the daily goings-on of life around hard things and difficult circumstances wonderfully. Sam Neill and Julian Dennison were great together. It was funny, smart, sweet. Highly recommend.
An absolute gem of a movie.
A warm funny coming of age story.
Didn't care for this one at all. Not a fan of Sam Neill.

Endearingly majestical. If movies have taught me anything, it's that Sam Neill may hate kids, but whether you're stuck on a sinking boat, running from dinosaurs, or lost in the bush, he's your best chance at survival.
Heartwarming and a set of vibrant characters. Great outdoor scenes and perhaps a great way to present New Zealand's beauty.
Funny, weird, darkly humorous, and full of heart. Taika Waititi really has a unique vision for his oddball films, Sam Neill slides effortlessly into the role of the cynical old man
Shades of Second Hand Lions.  Old grumpy guy, kid that needs love.  Anyway - we loved it.
A fun and funny quest film with excellent performances by Sam Neil and his young co-star.
AN ABSOLUTE MUST-SEE! Yet another heart-wrenching, funny and beautiful movie directed by the incredible Taika Waititi. This movie will satisfy anyone with a working brain.
Hilarious and original
Comedy and writing was witty and way more clever than the trailers let on. The characters are endearing and the emotional points hit harder than expected
The story moves quick and does whatever it wants. How it should be.

Nice little gem about a foster kid who finds stability in the outback of New Zealand.  Why can't Hollywood make movies like this anymore?  This one actually had me laughing out loud in some places.  It is a feel good movie that keeps your attention throughout.  Just a good all around film that is perfect for anyone, and is worth every minute.  Great for Saturday night.  Sausage?

Hilarious. The way Dennison and Neill work off each other is brilliant. The cinematography is gorgeous too. But felt like the film went off its path in the last quarter which messed with the pace. That's kind of typical of Waititi films though. (78%)

"Hunt for the Wilderpeople" is extremely hard to grade, because, like Taika Waititi's other movies, this one is so well made.  The acting and editing are perfect, but the story is just not interesting at all to me.  I give it a D, just don't bother.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a comedy with an original premise, likable characters and beautiful visuals, and still somehow manages to be more than the sum of its parts.
One of NZ's greatest movies lol
One of the most beautiful movies i've ever seen
What a truly amazing movie!!!! A masterclass in film making. It never misses a beat.
Absolutely beautiful film. I loved it

A wholesome film with laughs all the way throughout. Partnered with 'majestical' shots of the landscape. A gripping adventure where two outcasts come together and grow together. The way Julian Dennison delivers his lines so effortlessly yet effectively is a testament to his talent.
Not sure what this movie was about except a grouchy old man and an annoying orphan trying to escape the authorities for reasons unexplained.  Couldn't wait for it to end.  No tears then, just relief.
My favourite movie. Hilarious, touching, and fun. I've loved it each time I've watched it.

just a great fun ride, you cannot not laugh at least once in this movie. and the humor isn't just childish, haha funny fart noise, humor. its actually good humor. the relationship between Ricky and is adopted father is natural and great. didn't like how they fell apart when they were captured but eh. and I'm not sure if they're making a sequel but the introduction of the rare bird in the weird ruins seems weird and unnecessary. a few things like this happen in the movie, some unnecessary things here and there, doesn't really break the movie for me. but in general its a great movie. you have to watch this movie.
Great movie to watch with your family and friends!
A heartbreaker. So funny. Warning: you will adopt a child and an old man if you watch this film.
Another one I really wanted to love but the characters/performances didn't reach me except for Bella.

Sentimental and family friendly while never being cloying, this enchanting film takes surprising turns as two lonely, difficult people form a strong and often funny bond.  You'll be smiling often, watching a different kind of love story in a remarkable setting.  And the conclusion more than pays off the wait.  Great job all around.
This was a great, family film.

Original. Creatively mixes 'A' class movie feel with both organically funny and a touch of over-the-top-yet-calculated goofy scenes. Engaging story built on raw life situations through which human emotions must work to heal.

A very funny movie with lots of quirky humor. Sam Neil plays the grumpy 'uncle' really well, and Ricky is such a lovable character, even though he is a turd! Awesome story and also shows the beauty of NZ.

A sweetly written film set in a stunning, beautiful landscape manages to be elevated to an entirely different level due to the unbridled chemistry between a veteran of acting and a child actor and an offbeat sense of humor that could only come from Taika Waititi.
A real gem of a movie.  Perfect for anyone who wants to be entertained and end up feeling better.
A pretty good movie. With nice scenery and well timed humor, this film is pretty solid ... but does nothing to impress.

Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a romping adventure that if somewhat overlooked, is a hidden gem in the Zealandian bush.  If you're familiar with the comedic mind of Taika Waititi (Thor Ragnarok, Jojo Rabbit) then you know an adventure with Waititi is not to be missed.  Here we are presented with the silly oddball characters we've come to know and love from Waititi, and indeed, Sam Niel's deadpan portrayal of an ornery uncle makes him the perfect foil for kid rebel Ricky Baker.  Notably, Waititi doesn't care if the film's plot wanders it means we'll journey towards new treasures and surprises, and for this reason the film really breathes and develops in unexpected and even "majestical" ways.  It's a film with a heart the size of Ricky Baker and as is the mark of the greatest of adventure stories, this is an adventure neither you nor the characters will want to end.
Anything by Taika Waititi ends up being phenomenal, this is no different.
So clever, creative, and funny.
Funny, quirky, deep and strangely intelligent for a movie that's pretty crazy.

Just exactly what I needed. All characters so dear. Story so crazy. Scenery just devastatingly beautiful. The kid is great. I kept asking myself, is that Sam Neill? Nahh, can't be. But those eyes! Yeah loved every single thing about this absolute delight.

This is a heartwarming, fantastical tale about an An abandoned orphan and his adopted uncle are running for their lives in the New Zealand bush. 
Themes of freedom, independence, family and love are touchingly told in this fantastical film by the wonderful Tiaka  Waititi  and brilliantly acted by Sam Elliot  and Julian Dennison.  

A must see. I will watch it again and again.
Nearly perfect and from one of the most shining independent filmmakers, WILDERPEOPLE is hilarious, emotionally resonant, and dry in the best ways, forming possibly Waititi's best film.
One of the greatest comedies ever made.
As usual Waititi perfectly balances cartoonish humour, with adventure and genuinely moving drama. The two leads play off each other marvellously.

Beautiful from start to finish. I was immediately captured by the quirky characters, interesting plot and superb script - had us laughing all the way through, and took me by surprise a few times, totally unsure of where it would go next, but eager to keep watching to find out. The story was told beautifully, with charm and warmth, and I just loved each character and how they perfectly complimented each other. The scenery was amazing, making me want to go on my own wilderpeople adventure, and the sound track matched the writing magnificently, adding to the emotion of the story and drawing me in further. I longed for a happy ending for Ricky, and he got one. I highly recommend this majestical film, and will definitely watch it again.
Such good vibes from this movie all around. Lovable characters, great humor in the writing, beautiful visuals and soundtrack. The side characters are SO fun. Def recommend :)
Extraordinary; to say the least.

Such an original, smart movie. 
Fun, quirky, I love it.

Hunt no longer for your weekend streaming watch - Hunt For the Wilderpeople is a pleasure trove of cinematic delight. What's wonderful here, is the love not only in the story but in the making of the film. Similar to watching a Scorcese or Tarantino flick, you can feel the care, specificity and joy that was put into creating this wild and wonderful tale about relationships, growth and the need for adventure. With a star turn from the young man (who shortly thereafter went on to Daredevil fame) it's an easy watch, littered with playful visuals, editing and ribald dialogue that will comfortably surprise and please you. The writer/ director has a sure hand in creating a very specific world/ tone/ vibe, and for those of us with a love for imagination and a childlike hunger for new possibilities and pleasurable mischief, you will enjoy this film and Waititi's others.
Really enjoyed the fun, funky, foreign-made movie.  Well-done.

Great watch, would watch again, and can recommend.

WARNING: Sad dog scene.

Julian Dennison ("Deadpool 2") and Sam Neill ("Jurassic Park") give an amazing performance as grumpy unlikeable pair of guys purposely lost in the wilderness.

For an "foster kid" trope, this movie really has it all.  I don't appreciate it's attempt to mimic "Up!" and that did sour my opinion a bit.  It starts, then waxes and wanes between drama and comedy.

You'll laugh, you'll cry, there is family love, romantic love, plenty of action, and more laughs.

Sometimes just going for a walk is all a man (or young man) needs. This movie is targeted toward a young audience but works well for older viewers as well. It's a fresh look at coming of age, regardless of age, by way of sweeping vistas and visually stunning landscapes. Grab some popcorn and get ready for a bit of drama, some laughs topped off with a happy ending.
Good laughs, nice story, talented cast.

Great fantastic phenomenal movie directed by Taika Waititi, sort of a rollercoaster of a movie starring a kid who will be Dennis some day, he was great and this old man who was also great. Taika watiti can never go wrong and his streak still lives and that's hard to do, only a handful of directors have good movies in a row, the last director to do that was wes Anderson but he had a couple of bad movies and so far of what I've seen from taika, nothing bad, just pure gold. I would 100 percent see this movie again and I can't wait to see what taika watiti does next. Plus the cinematography is phenomenal like the directing and acting.
This movie is funny, and deals with hardships in a very comical way. The music and scenery is amazing. This is one of my favorite films. I highly recommend watching this one!
Great story! Solo funny!
Funniest quirky movie I have seen in years. Thoroughly enjoyed it and you should too.
This was great! This was charming and quirky like a Wes Anderson film, but Sam Neil's performance made it real.
The skug life chose me.
Julian Dennison plays his role magnificently, and absolutely carries the movies comedy.

Amazing movie about the unexpected adventure of a young, rebellious, and oblivious boy and an old, hardened, and independent man. Only, as the plot progresses, it can be seen that the seemingly opposite characters of the boy and man are actually very much alike, and it allows them to grow in a true friendship. The story leaves you with a heartfelt message of wholesomeness, humor, and friendship, and once again proves the age old saying: "Never judge a book by its cover."
It took me a minute to get used to the style but well worth the watch.

I loved watching every minute of this movie. It's humor is simple so that a kid can enjoy and understand it, and it's emotional aspect is complex enough that it can appeal to a mature audience. It's so rare these days that you find films like these that can appeal to everyone in the audience, but Taiki Waititi does an exceptional job with this. It was so much fun watching a boy and a man who are complete opposites form a close father and son relationship. Well with being stuck in the woods for five months while a manhunt conducted by government is after them they don't have a choice but to learn to know one another and form a close, unusual bond. Taika Waititi is starting to become one of my favorite directors/writers of all time.
This movie kept my attention and my interest. I was hooked until the end credits came rolling onto the screen
If you need a laugh and a cry, this is a great movie for that!
Hilarious and well-assembled

It has everything I would want in a movie 
My grade: A-
Great movie about intergenerational friendship. Loved the humor and the chemistry of the main characters. Also filmed in a beautiful location of New Zealand. Enjoyed it much more than Jojo Rabbit.
Everyone low-key loves this odd movie. 9/10.
You'd be hard-pressed to not enjoy this film.
Emotional tale of a crazy adventure. Heartwarming and tense - would recommend
Loved it, very entertaining on many levels. Great acting, comedy, adventure and a good message. I will be watching it again.
With its solid cast, talented direction and emotionally affecting message, it's a charming and entertaining viewing experience.
HFTW has everything you want in a film. It feels familiar but fresh, while being poignantly sad and dryly funny at the same time. NZ's beautiful backdrop tops it all off. Hunt no more.
Sadly, not enough people know this movie.
Understated movie-making magic.
This is a movie with a healthy dose of laughs and heart. Absolutely spectacular and hopeful.
Bumped this up to a 4 on a rewatch.  Neill and Dennison are the highlights with their very good chemistry and funny characters (I love the Ricky Baker character).  Fun stuff.
this is funny and full of heart
Great representation of New Zealand
A great adventure movie which injects the feel good factor and comedy, amongst a situation with a child in the foster system finally feeling at home
One of the more exciting and inventive films I've ever seen. A great showcase of humor (though often dark humor.) In short, a must-watch "feel good" movie.
Adored it.  Great chemistry, funny, beautiful, touching.  What is else is required in a movie?  Were there silly or unlikely bits?  Sure---go with the flow.

I love this movie. It's a perfect mix of humor and heart and it takes itself just seriously enough. Looking past the story (which is phenomenal), the cinematography and score are beautiful. This is a movie that really makes you care about its characters, leading to a meaningful and satisfying ending.
If you have any inner-child you (and that child ) will love this.
This movie about a boy and a man adventures through the bush getting away from the cops is great and really keeps you entertained:)
Another funny yet sensitive movie by Taika Waititi about a fat boy and his foster father  running away from child care service after the mother died.

If you know anything about my taste in film, you will know that Taika Waititi is my favorite director of all time. I've always found that his comedic, dramatic, and visual styles are always blended in a perfect way. Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a perfect example of this, if it weren't for Jojo Rabbit, this would definitely be Taika's best. Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a story about how family can come from the unlikeliest of places in the hardest times. The protagonist, Ricky Baker, is a perfectly cast teenage rebel who is put into a foster family where he meets Aunty, who really takes care of him. Without spoiling anything, the film really is an emotional roller coaster. Ricky Baker's Journey of learning of life away from being a selfish brat is complimented by the journey of "Uncle" Hector, who learns to accept others and open up to new experiences. The film really delves into how relationships can be made in tough situations. Now, all of this makes it sound like an absolute drag, and really, it isn't. This film is absolutely hilarious, and on point with Taika's usual comedic style. Unlike Taika's other work (excluding Thor: Ragnarok), this movie is full of wonderful action. The way that the entire film is set up really makes these extreme action sequences an extreme joy. The soundtrack is also really fun and different. Still, I found that the movie did suffer from quite a few jokes that didn't land. And the ones that did were sometimes done just a little short. At the very end of the movie, I feel like there needed to be more, and another half an hour could have easily made the story a lot more flushed out and complete. Still, this movie checks all of the boxes for me, and it's one of Taika's best. I'll give this one a 9.3/10
A nice little film with some big laughs and a daft ending
Love this movie and the dogs are awesome

Taika Waititi has consistently shown me that he makes good movies with the type of quirky humour and cinematography I thought I would only get from one other director W.A., but he has his own way about it :)
Love the story. It's absolutely an amazing movie with a beautiful story. The actors are spot on. Bought the movie and keep watching it over and over.

Intensely funny but with plenty of emotional impact. Plenty of influence from Wes Anderson is evident, but ultimately Waititi finds his own distinct style that is thoroughly enjoyable for just about everyone. (5/5)

It is very heart-warming, the actors and actresses did an incredible job, and the lines are particularly well-written, but somehow I feel like this topic has been covered before, so a bit lack of newness.

Such a special film. Beautifully layered narrative and pathos that's all wrapped up in hilarious, laconic comedy. The backdrop of the NZ wilderness is truly something amazing to behold. Oh and Julian Dennison just the most fantastic job!
Filled with hilarious humour, great cast and has a fantastic story.
Humorous and endearing, and strikingly suggestive of a live-action remake of Pixar’s ‘Up.’

Great fun movie and its brilliant.
Very solid movie.

I remember thinking this movie looked interesting, but wasn't sure. I was surprised how many times this movie made me burst out laughing. It did an excellent job of being funny, exciting, and hitting you right in the feels. 4/5⭐️

Yet another funny, original, and meaningful work by Taika Waititi.  Hunt for the Wilderpeople is delightful, and features the vastly underappreciated Sam Neil in one of his finest roles.  He's always been so much more than "that guy from Jurassic Park," and it really shows here.
Quality and totally recommend this fabulous movie! Can't wait for Hunt for the wilder people 2!
I was supposed to laugh.. I didn't.

Hunt For The Wilderpeople is really an unusual movie in a  good way. This movie from Taika Waititi is funny, unique, and amazing. I love the performances of Sam Neill and Julian Dennison, the screenplay, and the humor. Overall, Sam and Julian survived this movie review by a thread. Or at least by a thorn form a tree.
Love how it has some of the same characters from “Eagle v.s. Shark”. Good little movie to watch.
Totally entertaining.  Full of heart and humor.  Nothing objectionable.  Wow!
It is a slow film, but still a good film. The story and the chemistry between the two main characters is just perfect.
Absolutely brilliant.
The balance of emotion and humor is perfectly encapsulated in this charming film about finding your place.
Beautiful. Hilarious. Heartbreaking but not to the point that it's hard to watch (like ‘Boy' was, for me). I love love loved this movie.
Just watch the thing.

Bloody fantastic! It's simply an enjoyable film. The acting is wonderful. The cinematography, pacing, scoring, and writing are wonderful. It's a very pleasant tale and Waititi does a great job. Sam Neil does excellent and Julian Dennison is splendid.
started off slow until the boy started talking , then it became very,  very funny.
It was hilarious! Honestly, a breath of fresh air after most predictable plot story lines. So many catchy phrases that I've taken away from it. An excellent movie.
One of my favorite movies. Characters are great. The accents make it even better. I've watched this over and over and love it more every time.
A comedy with a huge heart it remind me for moments to Wes Anderson's movies
Great quirky feel good movie. Great shots reminiscent of west Anderson with out the over bearing artsy feel. Is a must see
Amazingly cute, funny and deep, and a 2 hour commercial for New Zealand tourism

This was a little slow, but surprising all the way.  The little guy - Julian - watch out for him.  He steals all the scenes and doesn't have to do anything but give you a look.  Of course it helps to have Sam Neill by your side.

New Zealand has some very nice movie products.  Their folk have a slightly dry but definitely effective funny bone.  It's a real pleasure.
This joins Parenthood as my favorite movie of all time

I knew I loved Taika Waititi but I hadn't seen this wonderful movie until last night and I think it's become one of my favorite movies of all time. Sam Neill and Julian Dennison are fucking delightful. I want pull both of them into a huge bear hug and never let go. Incredible acting to be able to portray these deeply wounded characters as bitter and cold in one moment, deeply longing and vulnerable in another, and then just completely hilarious in others. The story is beautiful (bless you Bella, you sweet, wonderful angel, too good for this world) and heartfelt and yet at the same time, you laugh through most of the movie. It doesn't remotely go in a direction you expect (at least not one I expected) despite initially seeming like it might be a familiar tale, it takes constant twists and turns through a delightfully deranged plot and keeps you constantly engaged while defying expectations. This is truly a perfect movie. I wouldn't change a thing ... except that I wish I saw it when it came out three years ago!!
Funny and deep, this heartfelt, action filled adventure brings us a fantastic beginning, and a satisfying conclusion among beautiful scenery and bold colors.
Funny and sweet. Hard to beat that.

A difficult foster child finally finds his place on a remote New Zealand farm, runs into some tough luck and goes on the lam with a stern, stoic older man who makes no attempt to disguise his contempt for the boy. Despite what sounds like a very serious, dreary premise, there's a lot of innocent joy, moments of pure brightness and continuous good humor in Hunt for the Wilderpeople.

While they evade pursuit in the Kiwi wilds, Ricky (the adoptee in question) stands up for himself and earns a place in the old man's heart, plus a dash of respect, without losing any of the magnetic, irreverent qualities that make him so much fun to watch. Youthful Julian Dennison is a great fit for the part, playing the hard-edged wannabe thug with a straight face while smoothly indulging the sillier ticks and quirks that make it clear he's still young at heart. Sam Neill, nearly unrecognizable beneath a thick white beard and thicker local accent, makes a fine addition as his gruff, prickly counterpart; a bitter, lonesome man who still harbors the spark of warmth beneath several prohibitive outer layers.

Sweet and genuine, effortlessly funny and smoothly charming, it's partly Napoleon Dynamite, partly Wes Anderson and partly its own thing entirely.

If there's one thing director Taika Waititi's known for, it's making something strange work. He most famously took Thor, a huge character in the massively successful Marvel Cinematic Universe, and completely reworked him from the ground up. Waititi made him funnier and added his signature quirk to that franchise, breathing new life into it. That style is as prevalent as ever in Waititi's adventure comedy, Hunt for the Wilderpeople, which he both wrote and direct. Sam Neil plays a bushman from New Zealand, who pairs up with Julian Dennison, portraying the juvenile delinquent orphan brought into his life, to form the kind of oddball, reluctant buddy combinations that work so well in these types of movies. 

Though the previous paragraph states, "these types of movies," there aren't many like this one. The buddy act is familiar, but everything else about the premise and setup feel unique. Ricky Baker (Dennison) is a hip-hop loving orphan who has been bounced around from foster home to foster home. To avoid juvenile detention, he joins Bella (Rima Te Wiata) and Hector (Neil), who live on a farm near the New Zealand bush. Bella is welcoming and endearing, though Hector is a bit distant. The strange new family ends up working out for everyone, until a tragic event puts Ricky on course to get sent back into child protective services. It sends him and Hector on a journey to avoid capture through the bush, thus forming the titular "wilderpeople."   

The past work of writer/director Taika Waititi was brought up earlier and for good reason. If you've seen and enjoyed his work in the past, you'll almost undoubtedly have a good time here. The quirky style of humor that made Thor: Ragnarok such a blast is evident here. Weird is funny and weird is Taika's calling card. The films blends so many things together to make for a unique experience. There's Ricky jamming to imaginary music while Hector watches in confusion. You have Bella killing a boar in front of Ricky in a gory, yet funny scene. There's also Ricky naming his dog after his favorite rapper/best friend, Tupac.

As noted, something about weirdness works excellently in Taika's favor. It's not just the case with the script, but with things like the music choices and the shots we get of the bush. For example, there's a blend of tracks included in the movie that fit the likes of the characters, as well as tone set from start to finish. Waititi did a strong job of using overhead shots panning across the bush to showcase just how immense it was. It really helped solidify the gravity of the situation for Ricky and Hector. The fact that it's a seriously frightening world for our heroes, yet it's brilliantly offset by the script and tone that Waititi puts together, is exactly why this film stands out.

There's also an interesting look on the class these characters come from. Neither are rich or well off, but they're still very different people. Ricky mostly embodies the kind of kid you'd expect from his generation and upbringing. He enjoys his music and the "gangster" life, while knowing nothing of the wilderness. When he gets told by Hector to use a leaf as toilet paper, it's a small exchange, yet one that captures why these two polar opposites work so well together. Their differences are the perfect ones to capture in the environment the film takes places in.

Ultimately, this is a movie that takes you on an enjoyable journey and is recommended, especially if you're looking for a laugh. There's a strong blend of action, suspense, surprising emotional beats, and great comedy. Waititi takes a somewhat simple premise and injects his brand of weird humor into it, turning it into something special. One watch of this film next to Thor: Ragnarok or Waititi's What We Do In The Shadows, and you can clearly see it all fits together. A Waititi film feels like a Waititi film from start to finish. That's a good thing.

Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a hidden gem. I wish more people knew about it. I only found out about it while looking for movies Sam Neill acts in. With it being an independent film I was hesitant, as I have not enjoyed too many of those types (although I do not view many of them). But I have to say, whoever cut their trailer did an amazing job. The trailer was so good that I feared it would outperform the movie. Luckily I was not disappointed. I think Sam Neill put it best when he said that this movie is not a comedy. It is a serious movie with funny things happening all around it. You will be laughing through much of the movie, but then the next moment you might be brought to tears. One of my favorite aspects of the movie is the realism and the freshness. If you are looking for a typical Hollywood blockbuster movie, then you will not find it here; and that is a good thing. The music, dialogue, and acting comes from fresh sources in New Zealand, and make for a new experience. One thing I like most about movies is being able to get sucked into the realism of it. It would not take too much to imagine this really happening. Just as nice as it is to have a veteran actor like Sam Neill, the new actors and actresses that this movie brings to the forefront shows that there are many more talented people out there than we may think. Everyone gave stunning performances. It makes me happy to know that some of them are moving on into Hollywood roles (like with Thor Ragnarok). The only reason for the lack of a full five stars is the amount of inappropriate language in it. That is something I find to be tactless and distasteful. I understand strong language in appropriate moments, but overuse of it shows a lack of imaginative dialogue. Overall I highly recommend you go see this movie.

Young characters are difficult to write. There's a balance between having the kid be too smart or too stupid. When that balance is achieved, you end up with a well-written character, but you're faced with another challenge: finding a performer capable of embodying that character. Thankfully, Julian Dennison does a perfect job alongside Sam Neill in this story of a foster kid who ends up in a home that is actually a nice place. It's a movie that shows that if you have a good heart, you can pass it to those whom you care about. Rachel House's hilarious performance as Paula, the Javert-like Child Welfare agent, shows that a job title isn't enough to actually have a heart.
This movie has a full gambit of emotions.  It's a great look at what it takes to be "home".
A great, sweet, charming movie for kids. And a good, sweet, charming movie for adults.

An uplifting movie that almost made me tear with laughter. Pretty much every line carried itself comedically. No matter how hard life can be there is always a place to find happiness. Even with the terrors Uncle Hec and Ricky went through they still found a light at the end of the tunnel and a bonding friendship. The story was very silly yet powerful, a great line carefully walked by Taika Waititi. The character development and acting were sensational.

"Sh*t just got real." This is a wonderful coming of age story as well as a story about how the bond between two males, one old and grief stricken, the other young and shut down, find healing in each other's company. The best kind of independent film. I can't recommend this too highly.

Charming, funny and whimsical, 'Hunt for The Wilderpeople' is a well-disguised drama that tackles serious topics and, ultimately, delivers a touching story full of heart. The fantastically eccentric characters are well written, but it's Sam Neill and Julian Dennison's portrayals that really brings them to life, with the latter stealing the show - put those two together and you end up with an unlikely, but absolutely magnetic on-screen duo. Really, I defy anyone to watch this and not leave feeling uplifted and satisfied.

A sweet, genuine, funny movie about a misfit rebel and his unwilling foster carer. Its hard to imagine Sam Neill in any other role other than Alan Grant in Jurassic Park, however he gives out a solid performance, striking up a unique partnership with Julian Dennison and the pair are a joy to watch together on screen.  The plot is well thought out, and moves at a fast enough pace to deliver an authentic sense of adventure. A rather different coming of age film, this film tackles some heavy issues in its own light hearted manner.  There's some impressive cinematography as well, making best use of New Zealand's stunning yet demanding landscape, however, that's not what the films about. It's about family, love and loss - themes aptly explored through a heartwarming adventure through New Zealand's wilderness.

Hunt for the Wilderpeople depicts a serviceable journey through its airy tone. Julian Dennison and Sam Neill make for a charming duo, carrying the film with their, more often than not, developing relationship, making for the most interesting aspect of the story. 
Waititi's style will not be for everybody, as some of the comedy does not land and can feel forced. Some character interactions often seem too random and incidental and, as a result, feel unearned. Additionally, Waititi's directing can sometimes feel inconsistent and distracting, depicting the characters' literal journey in a manner that makes it seem rushed and unconvincing. 
Ultimately, it's through Hunt's for the Wilderpeople's charming leads and jaunty tone that makes the film average at best. 2.5/5

Bella and Hector, two reclusive country folk, become foster parents to Ricky, a problem child from the city.  After some adjustment, things go reasonably well. However, the death of Bella means Hector now has to look after Ricky, and they didn't get along too well.  Moreover, her death causes Child Services to decide to send Ricky back to the orphanage.  Ricky refuses to go back and runs away, ultimately sparking a national manhunt for him and Hector.

Sweet, funny movie, written and directed by Taika Waititi who wrote and directed the superb vampire-comedy, What We Do In The Shadows (plus, more recently, directed Thor: Ragnarok).  

Starts slowly, with only a smattering of humour and limited engagement.  However, from a point it ramps up.  The humour comes thicker and faster, you start to root for the characters and the plot becomes quite interesting.  Some great scenes - the ones involving Psycho Sam (Rhys Darby) being the pick of the bunch.

Overall, not too powerful nor poignant, but very funny, interesting and full of heart.

8/10

Taika Waititi has done it again! Hunt for the Wilderpeople is an absolute gem that deserves more recognition than it got. A comedy from New Zealand with a lot of heart, Hunt for the Wilderpeople is about Ricky, a defiant city kid who is getting a fresh start with a foster family in the countryside. However when tragedy strikes he and his uncle Hec go into the wild and a crazy man hunt ensues. This is such a fun film, Julian Dennison as Ricky is absolutely hilarious and charismatic and Sam Neill as the curmudgeonly Hec is wonderfully dry in his humour. Rhys Darby also has a great little part as Psycho Sam and Rachel House as Paula is perfectly straight faced and funny as a child welfare worker who hates kids. The premise of the grumpy old man transformed by a loveable young scamp isn't exactly an original premise but this film hits such a good balance between the fantastical, humorous, sad and sweet that you can't help but love it.

A funny, adventurous tale set in the New Zealand bush, about a rowdy child placed in foster care with a poor childless couple. Sam Neill, of Jurassic Park fame, plays the illiterate boar-hunting foster dad. Older kids will love this movie.

Hunt for the Wilderpeople is a charming little film from New Zealand by director Taika Waititi. It tells of a young man who has been shuffled through the foster care system, but he just might have found a place where he belongs. However when the situation changes hes at risk of being sent back into the system, so he must go on the run. The adventure of Ricky and Hec through the wild is funny and endearing. It has all the elements of a good road trip movie and a good man-on-the-run movie combined.

Julian Dennison was basically an unknown before this movie, but I expect him to become a big name soon. He's got great comedic timing, and plays the emotional stuff well, which is a combo that can be hard to find in young actors. Sam Neill is perfect as the straight man throughout the film. He seems to be channeling a little of Alan Grant and has that reluctant fatherly connection with the young boy. Also of note is Rachel House who plays a psychotic CPS worker that adds so much comedy to the film. 

For me, the strongest part of Hunt for the Wilderpeople is the humor. It isn't exactly laugh-out-loud hilarity, but it features characters who make a number of incongruous choices that had me chuckling a lot. The character development is also strong for the two leads so I did care about their journey. I guess my only real complaint is that the emotional moments didn't hit me all that hard. I cared but never felt personally engaged in any way. Despite this I'm quite excited for Waititi to direct the next Thor film, because I think he could make it something unique and special.

Hunt For The Wilderpeople proved to be a very real, poignant film with actors on their A-game. Definitely worthy of a 4-star rating.

WHAT I LIKED: 'Hunt for the Wilderpeople' is one of the most delightful and humbling movie experiences out there, as its overall aims, and the charm with which it's all dealt, strips your own feelings of joy right back to their cores. Yes in building everything around two beautifully constructed people and a relationship with the natural world, the film really touches you somewhere deep down and brings a warm sense of joy and a humanity of its own. Layer on top Taika Waititi's fantastic whit and quirky style, and the happiness-factor is only upped, resulting in a rather poetic, genuinely wonderful film indeed.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: It is fairly simple, but its appeal is well-routed.
VERDICT: One of the best films of 2016, and one of my personal all-time favourites - this film's got soul, and that triumph sits mostly in the hands of Taika Waititi.

Hunt for the Wilderpeople Will Leave You Feeling Silly 

Hunt for the Wilderpeople is honestly one of the quirkiest films I've seen in awhile, in the vein of Flight of the Conchords and Arrested Development. While the film is packed full of laughs, delightful one liners and a myriad of unpredictable circumstances, the message and content are a little bit heavier. The flick insightfully contrasts the need we all feel to belong to a family with the process of overcoming the feelings of vulnerability and wariness that come from letting ourselves care about other people and depend on them. Packed all together, Hunt for the Wilderpeople will make you feel all the feels and still leave you positively beaming. 

As Ricky, (Julian Dennison), is dropped off at a farm on the edge of the New Zealand bush, the portly 10-year-old realizes his dreams of the thug life may have come to an abrupt halt. Ricky "the real bad egg" Baker has been in and out of foster and group homes all his life, and Ricky knows his new placement at the farm is his last shot to be part of a family before he's sent to juvenile detention. His new Auntie Bella (Rima Te Wiata) and Uncle Hec (Sam Neill) take a different approach to his care than previous foster parents; Bella is unperturbed by his attempts to run away and ignores his glum attitude, while Hec just plain ignores him. In fact, when Ricky asks Hec if there is anything he can do to help out on the farm, Hec firmly tells him to just "stay out of my way". Despite their individual quirks, such as Ricky's penchant for expressing himself via haiku and Bella's overbearing cheer, the little group grows into something resembling a family. 

When tragedy strikes the budding family, leaving Hec a widower and Ricky without a mother figure, social-services opts to take the child out of the less than perfect situation. However, Ricky is reluctant to be another kid lost in the system, and decides to take matters into his own hands.  Thinking he can carve out a life on his own, he runs into the bush. It's soon apparent that his questionable survival skills won't be enough to keep him out of trouble, and surprisingly, Hec, with his wilderness know-how, comes to his rescue. Whilst making their way out of the bush, Ricky discovers that Hec is unable to read and taunts him about his ineptitude. When Hec gets angry and chases after Ricky, an accident renders Hec unable to leave the forest, forcing the duo to begrudgingly spend several weeks together in the wild.

As the pair spend time together they begin to learn to rely on each other. With Hec being unable to walk, he has to tell Ricky how to find food and buld shelter to keep them alive. When they get into a scuffle with a couple of hunters, Ricky uses his street knowledge (namely a rifle and some choice words) to save Hec from the men that want to separate them. One of my favorite scenes shows Hec and Ricky snuggled up in sleeping bags next to the campfire, and Ricky is reading to Hec. It's heartwarming and hilarious to watch as they grow to lean on each other and recognize that they are stronger when they work together. Not only that, but that it's preferable to let other people into our lives and hearts than try to do everything alone. 

Director Taika Waititi ("Boy" and "What We Do in the Shadows") turns prominent New Zealand writer Barry Crump's story, "Wild Pork and Watercress", into a deeply inspiring and off-the-wall comedy flick that everyone can enjoy. While the wacky situations throughout the film (my favorites include the Happy Birthday song and Lord of the Rings reference) move the story along, Julian Dennison and Sam Neill steal the spotlight in this eccentric adventure. They perfectly demonstrate the internal struggle involved with the almost alien act of opening up and being vulnerable with those you care about. Ricky and Hec's transformation from two closed off loners to an unlikely family makes this film truly "majestical".

Hunt for the Wilderpeople: A uniquely emotional comedic relief

A heart wrenching, gut-busting, comedy-drama film, Hunt for the Wilderpeople makes it to the top of the list when it comes to best films of 2016. This quirky, yet lovable movie is beautiful not only in the cinematography but the development of the emotions both in the characters and audience. Young Ricky Baker played by Julian Dennison is a 13-year-old foster-child wannabe gangster. He's placed in the hands of the quiet Uncle Hec (Sam Neil) and affectionate Aunt Bella (Rima Te Waita) on their small farm in the middle of New Zealand. Life takes an unexpected turn forcing Ricky and Uncle Hec to travel deep into "the Bush" on the run from child welfare officer Paula (Rachel House).

It's a completely ridiculous storyline yet somehow director, Taika Waititi pulls it all together to create another brilliant piece of art similar to his other witty-natured movies Eagle vs Shark and Boy. His prominent style throughout most of his films include the occasional prolonged scene creating that on-edge humor that can feel cringe worthy, but also makes it absolutely impossible not to laugh. The awkward but endearing moment between Ricky and Hec, sharing their haikus is the scene that makes this movie so noteworthy. These are two of the most closed off characters when it comes to expressing emotions. Within one scene, those emotional barriers break down to expose the true feelings of these rugged outlaws. Waititi masters capturing this heartwarming scene through the perfect balance of humor and affection, proving that it doesn't take tears to get an emotional point across.  

With a Wes Anderson style, the whole movie is both pleasing to the eye, all while tugging at your heart strings. It's hard not to enjoy the character Ricky Baker; haikus and all. With his eye for simplicity, Waititi sets a high standard for future comedy-drama films. This artsy film is overflowing with incredibly simple, yet stunning visuals. Because it's based off of the book, Wild Pork and Watercress by Barry Crump, he brilliantly overlays the chapter headings from the book onto beautiful shots of New Zealand countryside as transitions from one part of the storyline to the next, giving it the storybook kind of feel. The whole film captures the beauty of New Zealand on a deeper level with Ricky, Uncle Hec, and their loyal dogs traveling through some of the thickest rainforests with only their keen sense of adventure to guide them.

Experiencing this film is honestly an adventure of your own. Throughout the piece it's not completely clear what you should be feeling, but that doesn't take away the fact that its charming, fun, emotional, and appealing. It will leave you with a sense of awe for the world of filmmaking and the minds that come up with these exceptional art pieces. Hunt for the Wilderpeople is ultimately an extraordinary rare masterpiece.

Neillâ??s wife in the movie, Bella, takes young Ricky in over Neillâ??s protestations and despite the young manâ??s record of stealing, spitting, graffittiing, burning and various other anti-social behaviors. Maybe it's just me or maybe it's just the fact that I'm on this side of the world, but I find that Taika Waititi is really underrated as a comedy filmmaker.  Even though some of his films (at least Boy and this one) contain some dramatic content.  Then again, he might not be underrated considering that he is directing the next Thor movie, so I have high hopes for that.  Anyway, the point of it all that I find Mr. Waititi to be an immensely talented filmmaker and actor.  One of the (many) things that I liked about Taika's style is that he clearly knows how to get the most out of his actor and he has a great eye for developing characters.  Even What We Do in the Shadows, a straight-up comedy, has some truly great and memorable characters.  Admittedly speaking, however, when compared to his previous two movies, this isn't as good as either of those two.  And that isn't even suggesting that this movie is bad, that's just how great Boy and Shadows really are.  I haven't seen Eagle vs Shark yet, so I wouldn't know what to say about that.  As it stands, there's a reason that this movie is the highest grossing film in New Zealand ever.  Which honestly, as good as this movie actually is, I find surprising, considering that the Lord of the Rings trilogy was filmed in New Zealand by a New Zealand director.  Maybe that trilogy wasn't as massive there as it was over here, which is entirely possible.  Either way, the fact of the matter is that this is a damn good movie with a strong focus on character development.  It's also a really funny movie as well.  It might not be as hilarious as Shadows.  While the comedy is Shadows was, overall, more laugh-out-loud than this movie, I think this movie was far more consistent.  Shadows dragged a little bit, whereas this movie didn't really drag.  I think that may be because there's also more than just comedy going on here, there's a narrative of the growing relationship between Ricky and Hector, Ricky's foster parent, after Hector's wife and Ricky's foster mother, a lovely woman, passed away due to a heart attack.  At least I assume since they didn't actually confirm her cause of death.  After her death, Ricky and Hector go on the run from the government, as they want to take Ricky back to juvenile hall.  Ricky's having none of this.  The movie gets some comedy from this, as during the manhunt that, in the climax, even the military gets involved (yes), it is rumored that Hector has been...sexually inappropriate with Ricky.  He obviously hasn't, but its silliness work in this setting.  And it's not like they harp on it too much, because that might have brought the movie to a darker place that they didn't want the story to go.  The narrative is pretty much what you would expect, since Hector starts out as a typical grumpy old man with Ricky.  Obviously, as the film progresses, Ricky and Hector start spending more time together and they start to grow fond of one another.  You've seen it before and you'll see it again.  But this movie does it with humor, heart and intelligence.  It also helps when you have a talented actor like Sam Neil as Hector.  Which brings us to Julian Dennison, who plays Ricky.  This kid is, quite honestly, a fucking natural.  The editing obviously has a lot to do with choosing the best takes, but the effort from the actor still has to be there.  And, like I said, the kid is a natural.  He's great in this movie.  He's likable, he's charismatic, surprising for someone his age, and, most importantly, he's funny.  He plays perfectly off of Sam Neil.  The supporting cast is really strong as well.  Rhys Darby has a memorable appearance as a conspiracy theorist who helps Ricky and Hector.  Taika has a role himself as the priest in one of the more memorable scenes of the entire movie.  If there's one thing you can't complain about, it's the cast.  Is the film sentimental?  In my view, no, not really.  At least not super sentimental, yes, there's some sweet moments or the end scene with the Ricky and Hector bantering.  But, and here's the difference, the movie earned those moments.  They're not forced upon you by characters you didn't care about.  At least that's how I see it, there's no big reunion between Ricky and Hector where a rousing, inspiration score plays in the background.  There is a reunion, but they don't make a big deal out of it, which is how it should be done.  With that said, the movie isn't perfect, it falls very short of hitting the great mark, but this is a real good movie that I would easily recommend.  It's an easy, funny watch with strong characters.  Can't go wrong with that.
